threads.author: porkcube
threads.content:
@aaa345343 ahhh ok its really unhappy about SDA/SCL set to -1, changing this in `variants/diy/seeed-xiao-nrf52840-wio-sx1262/variant.h` should get you going:```#define PIN_SERIAL1_RX (-1)
#define PIN_SERIAL1_TX (-1)
#define PIN_WIRE_SDA (6)
#define PIN_WIRE_SCL (7)```

threads.author: porkcube
threads.content: remove the existing PIN_SERIAL1_RX/TX using pins 6/7 and PIN_WIRE_SDA/SCL set to -1 and use those while i have a shameful cry in the corner and PR the fix üòû

threads.author: anna_streeter
threads.content:
.
Subject: Flashing Station G2 with Missing SW3 Button
.
Any Station G-2 users out there?

Firmware Upgrading the Station G2 includes pressing the RST (SW3) button, specifically holding down SW2 while single pressing SW3.  But SW3 might break off while you're attempting the upgrade. 
No Worries
This worked perfectly, well, i'll go thru the flash steps for flashing without a SW3 button.  Hope you enjoy this. 
.....
 On your computer AND you cell phone.....
Bluetooth Settings ---> Perform "FORGET" on your Station G3's Bluetooth ID showing up in the list.
USB2 to USB-C cable to your Pee Cee, then you use the Chrome browser.
Stn G2---> Remove black metal cover (opposite the side with the screen). 
Admire the circuit board üôÇ
Chrome---> flasher.meshtastic.org website, pick Station G2
Open it, go past the agree page, choose full install but do NOT chose the web UI option. 
Connect USB cable
Press & Hold SW2, and then single press SW3, Wait 5 sec and release
If SW3 button is missing, use flat head screwdriver to short the solder points of SW3
And now the Station G2 is in the RST-Mode
Start the flashing on the website. 
After it's done, you might have to single press (or short the solder points) briefly to get it out of RST mode.  
Unplug USB to power down, plug back in. 
Use the iPhone Meshtastic app to do your new settings.  You can't diddle with the settings
on your Mac until you get done using iPhone. 
All done, and your Station G2 will start kicking ass again. 
Remember to keep antenna connected.   Enjoy !!!
.

threads.author: neilrf
threads.content: that switch isn't the only way to upgrade the firmwareüòÄ . There is a 1200bps button in the web flasher (see the attachement ), which can be used to enter the bootloader using software. In fact, any serial port software can be used to connect to the ESP32 S3 MCU using 1200bps to let the mcu enter the bootloader mode.

threads.author: jackint0sh
threads.content:
Yeah, Seeed's guide isn't the easiest to follow, but you'll need to reflash the bootloader to get it back online.

Make sure you have adafruit-nrfutil installed and the bootloader .zip downloaded from here:
https://wiki.seeedstudio.com/sensecap_t1000_e/#device-bricked

And you can try one of these scripts:
https://gist.github.com/jeremiah-k/9b3891e432784edf17a9ff5583b03a95 (dfu-retry.bat - windows)
https://gist.github.com/jeremiah-k/6bf1517927e18961813dd377a389f1e8 (dfu-retry.sh - linux/mac)

The scripts might need a little adjustment, they're similar to the one I used last time but cleaned up a bit more (these versions are untested though).  Then it's just:

```
dfu-retry.bat COM3
```
(Adjust for the appropriate port)

threads.author: jackint0sh
threads.content:
Have you or has anyone else had trouble pairing a rak while using this bootloader?  It worked fine for me if there was an existing bond, but I had to revert this change in order to pair a new device.
https://github.com/oltaco/Adafruit_nRF52_Bootloader_OTAFIX/compare/master...jeremiah-k:Adafruit_nRF52_Bootloader_OTAFIX:fix/rak-ble-pairing
